story:
Roller Coaster Crawls to End Alzheimer's 2014

Background

My brother, Kevin J. Moran (1958-2012), was a father, husband, lawyer & an avid roller coaster enthusiast. At age 51, Kevin was diagnosed with early-onset Alzheimer's Disease. After a short three-year battle, he succumbed to complications from the disease and passed away at age 54 in 2012.

To honor his memory and to raise funds & awareness for the ongoing fight against Alzheimer's Disease, in the spring & summer of 2013, I set out to ride 100 roller coasters in 100 days, taking pledges from friends, relatives & supporters per-ride and raised over $9,000 by the time of my Walk to End Alzheimer's event in October 2013. The nickname of my fundraising team is "Kevin's Koasters."

Many of the smaller amusement parks "comped" my admission fees as I was riding & raising money for charity. Unfortunately, the larger, more corporate amusements parks have very involved rules for their charitable contributions and very short windows to submit requests. I do not mind buying a season pass for Six Flags parks, as it is a very good deal if one plans to got to a park 3 times or more (which I did in 2013, and hope to do again this year).

What We Need

I would very much like to repeat the success of last year's tour.

As you might expect, traveling the Northeast on the 2013 tour took a personal financial toll on me with gas & travel costs. While I was able to raise a ton of money for charity, I also put myself in a bit of a hole financially with travel, accommodation & park admission costs.

This Indiegogo campaign is strictly to help offset my travel & accommodations costs as much as possible in 2014. I have already purchased my 2014 Six Flags season pass, but now I need to fund the travel costs needed to visit as many Six Flags parks as possible to reach my 100 coaster ride goal. The preliminary itinerary includes the following Six Flags parks (shown with approximate round-trip travel miles):

  • Six Flags Great Adventure, Jackson, NJ (720 miles)
  • Six Flags New England, Agawam, MA (630 miles)
  • Six Flags Great Escape, Lake George, NY (490 miles)
  • Six Flags Great America, Gurnee, IL (1,300 miles)
  • Six Flags Le Ronde, Montreal, QC Canada (700 miles)
  • Six Flags America, Marlboro, MD (760 miles)

Depending on funding received, other coaster crawls may be planned as well including Texas & California!

Any funds raised above & beyond the cost of travel & accommodations will be donated to the cause, the Alzheimer's Association of the Rochester/Finger Lakes region.

What You'll Get

In addition to taking donations for riding rollercoasters, Kevin's Koasters also is fundraising by selling imported gourmet coffee, another one of Kevin's passions.

To encourage & reward you for helping to fund our tour, we will offer the following perks for donors at the following levels:

  • $10 - One (1) purple Alzheimer's Association awareness silicone bracelet
  • $25 - One (1) 12 oz package of Kevin's Koasters Coffee, one (1) bracelet
  • $50 - One (1) 12 oz package of Kevin's Koasters Coffee, one (1) tie-dye Kevin's Koasters logo t-shirt, one (1) bracelet

Q: Should I contribute to travel costs or donate to the cause?

PLEASE NOTE: This is NOT a donation to the Alzheimer's Association or my Walk to End Alzheimer's fundraising. It is quite frankly "travelin' money" for the rollercoaster tour. Gas, hotel, theme park admissions, dare I say airline tickets & rental cars?

Obviously, we would like you to contribute to the both the charitable cause and to the travel costs campaign.

If contributing to the travel costs campaign will prevent you from contributing to the actual fundraiser, then please contribute to the fundraiser as the more important mission here is money to #ENDALZ.

Our hope is that through this campaign, we'll attract some corporate donors to either contribute to our travel costs financially or with in-kind donations such as park admissions, rental cars, or airline flights! That way, we can direct individual donors to the actual Alzheimer's Association fundraising effort.

Links of interest

  • Roller Coaster Crawls to End Alzheimer's Facebook page
  • Kevin's Koasters Coffee online ordering website
  • Kevin's Koasters Facebook page
  • Rochester Walk to End Alzheimer's donor page
  • My YouTube page featuring news coverage & coaster rides from last year!

Thank you for your time, consideration & continued support!

Michael A. Moran
mm@KevinsKoasters.org
Rochester, NY

story:
Hi deep freediving addicts!

After the success of our last crowfundings, we are happy to introduce the Octopus fluid goggles!

Fluid goggles are a great tool to bring safety, relaxation and enjoying seeing underwater, without having to worry about equalizing the goggles, and without any depth limit. Our model allows to see underwater and on the surface too. 

Being able to see on the surface, and not only underwater, is a significant bonus... It makes the pre-dive preparation more relaxed, and the surface protocol much easier in competition.

 Underwater, once you get used to it (it takes a few sessions, just like when you start to use a noseclip), being able to see perfectly makes you feel more serene, especially in case of problem such as your lanyard getting tangled. Finally, for your fun-dives, you'll be able to enjoy the beauty of the underwater world without having to worry about equalizing a mask.

The width of the googles can be tuned with the 4 different size nose bridge delivered with to fit your specific face ergonomic. 

Producing the type of tailor-made goggle structure we have designed requires a large investment for the injection mold, but this is the only option to offer goggles with double vision (underwater and on the surface), of optimal quality, with a perfect positioning of the lenses, unparalleled comfort, a killer design and still super affordable.

 

 

The amazing Eric Fattah designed the very first models around 20 years ago. Back then, lenses were included too inside the goggles. This was semi-handicraft work, produced only in small series, and therefore with a fairly expensive price tag of around 200-300 USD.

For the past few years, the various models found on the market were made using regular swimming goggles, in which two holes were made to house the lenses. However, this meant you could no longer see anything on the surface, since the lenses could not be fitted in the inner space of standard swimming goggles: that space is too small and the lenses would be too close to the eyeballs. Moreover, piercing holes inside swimming goggles takes time: such fluid goggles are produced in small quantities and remain expensive. 

 

 

 

So… How can we keep such an affordable price?

(compared to the fluid goggles already available on the market? )

3 main points: 

- Instead of buying a pre-existing model of goggles and tampering with it so that it can host the lenses, we will be producing the goggle structure ourselves instead, using a super-strong polycarbonate. Once the big initial investment to produce the molds is done, then the production costs for this tailor-made goggle structure is fairly low, since we work directly with the producer.

- Regarding the top-quality lenses, in order to keep a competitive price, we ordered several thousand pieces from one of the best producers of lenses in the world. This enabled us to considerably lower the price per unit. 

- Finally, we will be using a smart pin system, onto which lenses can be clipped. As they will remain inside the goggles, we do not need to handle the time-consuming and expensive process of piercing holes in the structure. Once the lenses are clipped into place, and unless you do a very specific maneuver, they are firmly fixed with no risk of losing them. 

 

 

 

 

Components

-Skirt and head-strap: top-quality silicon

-Structure: polycarbonate 

-Lenses: top-quality 20mm planoconvex

 

 

Be the first to pre-order your new Octopus fluid goggles, at a great discounted price!!! Production will start in September 2020, and delivery is planned for late October 2020. 

Enough words, the video speaks for itself!!!

A warm thank you for your support!

Pascal.

story:
NOW AVAILABLE on DRAGONtail Tenkara website

 

Mutant zx380 Zoom Tenkara Fly Fishing Rod

The Ultimate 3-Length Full-Flex Action ZOOM Tenkara Rod
      380cm (12.5ft), 350cm (11.5ft), and 315cm (10.3ft)
Covering 3 of the most popular lengths in one Totally Awesome Tenkara Rod

Planned Retail Price: $160 (save $40 when you support our Indiegogo Product Launch)

Features/Performance Overview:

Zoom sections lock to give you 3 adjustable lengths in one rod (sometimes called a triple zoom rod) so you can use the same rod for all the different conditions you run into on the water. Whether you want long reach, a medium casting length, or need to shorten things up around over hanging trees this MUTANT zx380 Tenkara Rod has you covered with just the zoom of a rod section (or two) mutating into the rod length needed.

Zoom Length Diagram below.

Excellently balanced tip-weight in every length, feels very light in hand when casting and fishing.

You’ll most likely love the rod action in every zoom length, not just 1 or maybe 2 like many other triple zoom rods.

Deep rod flex action allows the rod to distribute pressure evenly throughout the entire rod when fighting fish. This deep rod flex also makes for a smooth casting action with little effort to cast light level lines.

Excellent tip dampening so you have very little (IF ANY) oscillation while casting giving you very precise accurate casts with great presentation, even with very light level lines.

This rod is designed for targeting small to medium sized trout on light lines in creeks, streams, or small rivers. That does not mean you can’t use outside of those parameters if you so desire, have fun doing what you like. Although if you want to target big fish then this is probably not the tenkara rod for you.

Review From Tom Davis (a highly trusted name in Tenkara)

We let Tom Davis (of Teton Tenkara Blog) take the prototype for a test drive, check out his review here >>

Tom’s Spec Measurements of the MUTANT Rod

Fully collapsed (with tip plug): 65 cm (25.5 inches)
Extended: 314, 351, 381 cm (10.3, 11.5, 12.5 feet)
Weight (without tip cap or plug): 81.5 g (2.87 oz)
CCS: 13 pennies (380cm), 12.5 pennies (350cm), 12 pennies (315cm)
RFI: 3.4 (380cm), 3.6 (350cm), 3.8 (315cm).
Rotational Moment: 6.1 (in the 380cm length)

Tom's Conclusion: "I really like this rod. As I have stated above, I think Brent and DRAGONtail have advanced tenkara in America by providing some really great products. The MUTANT is just another rod that shows that they listen to the needs of their customers. The MUTANT is well made, and performs wonderfully! If you are a full flex tenkara rod person, and are in the market for a new rod, then you ought to take a look at the DRAGONtail MUTANT zx380! I think you'll be pleased!"

NEW TO TENKARA: Why a Tenkara Fishing Rod?

Ultra Compact - Tenkara rods telescope out and in so you can have a fly fishing rod that is over 12ft long collapsed down to 2ft and all self contain within its self with very little weight and very little size. No reel is needed and very minimal gear is required: rod, flies, line, and tippet. This makes it perfect for backpackers, day hikers, back country biking, keeping in the car, or anywhere adventure takes you!

Simple To Start - Although there are many Tenkara fishing techniques that you can spend years learning and perfecting, it is easy to get started with the basics and start catching fish. The basic casting motion is simple, the gear is simple, and setup is very quick (see our setup videos). The light line and long rod make for great presentation of your fly as you can keep your line out of the currents so your fly makes a natural drift with very little effort, making your fly more desirable to fish with very little experience on your part.

It's Fun As Hell - You would be surprise how much you will enjoy this simple form of fly fishing. We get messages all the time telling us "I have been fishing (or fly fishing) for 20-30 years and I just fell in love with fishing all over again using your Tenkara rods". Me personally, I was addicted to Tenkara the second I got my first fish on it and the fun is still very alive today.

Our MUTANT Design Story

DRAGONtail has listened to people in the tenkara community over the years through comments, messages, conversations, and even reading though peoples rant posts. From paying attention to the tenkara community we have learned many things about what people want, like, and don’t like.

We decided to we needed a rod more focused on premium level line casting in our DRAGONtail lineup. But I didn’t just want a nice level line rod, I also wanted to do a 3-length zoom level line casting rod that covered the most popular rod lengths and that felt excellent in each zoom length. Many people don’t believe that is possible to achieve in a 3-length tenkara rod but we went for it anyway, and I feel like we have actually succeeded in that with the current prototype of the MUTANT Tenkara rod design.

We have been working on this rod design for quite some time and finally made a lot of progress getting it the to performance level we wanted it to be late last year. After finishing our co-creation project of the MIZUCHI Tenkara Rod with Tom Davis (of Teton Tenkara) for tight fishing quarters last summer we learned many design elements that helped move the MUTANT rod prototype design progress to a whole new level of performance.

(By the way, conversations with Tom Davis through out the years and reading through his blog posts has been very enlightening us and an influence in many in many things we do here at DRAGONtail. We thank him for always sharing his thoughts and experiences.)

This last rod prototype our factory completed for us is more than we could have hoped for, we are very pleased. We are so excited to finally move forward from prototyping the MUTANT rod to now setting up production of the new rod and introducing it publicly.

Our MIZUCHI Tenkara Rod has been very popular since it’s launch last September and people seem to be loving the rod for fishing tight quarters on small creeks and streams, like many of the creeks Tom Davis fishes. We are so happy to soon have the new MUTANT tenkara rod to cover the longer rod lengths for fishing more open casting areas (my kind of water) and still have a shorter length (10.3ft) to make casting in many tighter casting quarters easier. Really with the MIZUCHI rod and the new MUTANT rod together you can fish just about any water situation in a preferred length.

We appreciate your contribution in helping us launch this excellent new tenkara rod, and we hope you enjoy the big discount you get for supporting us on this product launch.

I really think a lot of tenkara anglers that prefer light level lines are going to love how this rod casts them with ease, although the rest of you are still going to like how smooth it casts most tapered lines as well.

It blows me away how much I like the MUTANT rod in each of the 3 zoom lengths, more so than any other zoom rod I have tried; and I have tried many from USA brands to Japanese brands, we do a lot of rod research here at DRAGONtail. I think you will be very pleased with the MUTANT rod’s performance for you.

Perks Available:

Mutant Tenkara Rod reward: You get the Mutant zx380 Tenkara Rod with hard case and rod sock.

Mutant Tenkara Rod w/Starter Kit reward: You get the Mutant zx380 Tenkara Rod with hard case, rod sock, spool of DRAGONtail Level Line (enough to make several different length lines), 2 line spools, 3 Tenkara flies, and a spool of tippet.

We guarantee the delivery of all the perks, our reputation depends on it and we are an established company with great reputation we want to keep.

Tenkara Addict Video Review of the Mutant Prototype

 

How To Use a Multi-Length Zoom Tenkara Rod
story_txt: NOW AVAILABLE on DRAGONtail Tenkara website Mutant zx380 Zoom Tenkara Fly Fishing RodThe Ultimate 3-Length Full-Flex Action ZOOM Tenkara Rod      380cm (12.5ft), 350cm (11.5ft), and 315cm (10.3ft)Covering 3 of the most popular lengths in one Totally Awesome Tenkara RodPlanned Retail Price: $160 (save $40 when you support our Indiegogo Product Launch)Features/Performance Overview:Zoom sections lock to give you 3 adjustable lengths in one rod (sometimes called a triple zoom rod) so you can use the same rod for all the different conditions you run into on the water. Whether you want long reach, a medium casting length, or need to shorten things up around over hanging trees this MUTANT zx380 Tenkara Rod has you covered with just the zoom of a rod section (or two) mutating into the rod length needed.Zoom Length Diagram below.Excellently balanced tip-weight in every length, feels very light in hand when casting and fishing.You’ll most likely love the rod action in every zoom length, not just 1 or maybe 2 like many other triple zoom rods.Deep rod flex action allows the rod to distribute pressure evenly throughout the entire rod when fighting fish. This deep rod flex also makes for a smooth casting action with little effort to cast light level lines.Excellent tip dampening so you have very little (IF ANY) oscillation while casting giving you very precise accurate casts with great presentation, even with very light level lines.This rod is designed for targeting small to medium sized trout on light lines in creeks, streams, or small rivers. That does not mean you can’t use outside of those parameters if you so desire, have fun doing what you like. Although if you want to target big fish then this is probably not the tenkara rod for you.Review From Tom Davis (a highly trusted name in Tenkara)We let Tom Davis (of Teton Tenkara Blog) take the prototype for a test drive, check out his review here >>Tom’s Spec Measurements of the MUTANT RodFully collapsed (with tip plug): 65 cm (25.5 inches)Extended: 314, 351, 381 cm (10.3, 11.5, 12.5 feet)Weight (without tip cap or plug): 81.5 g (2.87 oz)CCS: 13 pennies (380cm), 12.5 pennies (350cm), 12 pennies (315cm)RFI: 3.4 (380cm), 3.6 (350cm), 3.8 (315cm).Rotational Moment: 6.1 (in the 380cm length)Tom's Conclusion: "I really like this rod. As I have stated above, I think Brent and DRAGONtail have advanced tenkara in America by providing some really great products. The MUTANT is just another rod that shows that they listen to the needs of their customers. The MUTANT is well made, and performs wonderfully! If you are a full flex tenkara rod person, and are in the market for a new rod, then you ought to take a look at the DRAGONtail MUTANT zx380! I think you'll be pleased!"NEW TO TENKARA: Why a Tenkara Fishing Rod?Ultra Compact - Tenkara rods telescope out and in so you can have a fly fishing rod that is over 12ft long collapsed down to 2ft and all self contain within its self with very little weight and very little size. No reel is needed and very minimal gear is required: rod, flies, line, and tippet. This makes it perfect for backpackers, day hikers, back country biking, keeping in the car, or anywhere adventure takes you!Simple To Start - Although there are many Tenkara fishing techniques that you can spend years learning and perfecting, it is easy to get started with the basics and start catching fish. The basic casting motion is simple, the gear is simple, and setup is very quick (see our setup videos). The light line and long rod make for great presentation of your fly as you can keep your line out of the currents so your fly makes a natural drift with very little effort, making your fly more desirable to fish with very little experience on your part.It's Fun As Hell - You would be surprise how much you will enjoy this simple form of fly fishing. We get messages all the time telling us "I have been fishing (or fly fishing) for 20-30 years and I just fell in love with fishing all over again using your Tenkara rods". Me personally, I was addicted to Tenkara the second I got my first fish on it and the fun is still very alive today.Our MUTANT Design StoryDRAGONtail has listened to people in the tenkara community over the years through comments, messages, conversations, and even reading though peoples rant posts. From paying attention to the tenkara community we have learned many things about what people want, like, and don’t like.We decided to we needed a rod more focused on premium level line casting in our DRAGONtail lineup. But I didn’t just want a nice level line rod, I also wanted to do a 3-length zoom level line casting rod that covered the most popular rod lengths and that felt excellent in each zoom length. Many people don’t believe that is possible to achieve in a 3-length tenkara rod but we went for it anyway, and I feel like we have actually succeeded in that with the current prototype of the MUTANT Tenkara rod design.We have been working on this rod design for quite some time and finally made a lot of progress getting it the to performance level we wanted it to be late last year. After finishing our co-creation project of the MIZUCHI Tenkara Rod with Tom Davis (of Teton Tenkara) for tight fishing quarters last summer we learned many design elements that helped move the MUTANT rod prototype design progress to a whole new level of performance.(By the way, conversations with Tom Davis through out the years and reading through his blog posts has been very enlightening us and an influence in many in many things we do here at DRAGONtail. We thank him for always sharing his thoughts and experiences.)This last rod prototype our factory completed for us is more than we could have hoped for, we are very pleased. We are so excited to finally move forward from prototyping the MUTANT rod to now setting up production of the new rod and introducing it publicly.Our MIZUCHI Tenkara Rod has been very popular since it’s launch last September and people seem to be loving the rod for fishing tight quarters on small creeks and streams, like many of the creeks Tom Davis fishes. We are so happy to soon have the new MUTANT tenkara rod to cover the longer rod lengths for fishing more open casting areas (my kind of water) and still have a shorter length (10.3ft) to make casting in many tighter casting quarters easier. Really with the MIZUCHI rod and the new MUTANT rod together you can fish just about any water situation in a preferred length.We appreciate your contribution in helping us launch this excellent new tenkara rod, and we hope you enjoy the big discount you get for supporting us on this product launch.I really think a lot of tenkara anglers that prefer light level lines are going to love how this rod casts them with ease, although the rest of you are still going to like how smooth it casts most tapered lines as well.It blows me away how much I like the MUTANT rod in each of the 3 zoom lengths, more so than any other zoom rod I have tried; and I have tried many from USA brands to Japanese brands, we do a lot of rod research here at DRAGONtail. I think you will be very pleased with the MUTANT rod’s performance for you.Perks Available:Mutant Tenkara Rod reward: You get the Mutant zx380 Tenkara Rod with hard case and rod sock.Mutant Tenkara Rod w/Starter Kit reward: You get the Mutant zx380 Tenkara Rod with hard case, rod sock, spool of DRAGONtail Level Line (enough to make several different length lines), 2 line spools, 3 Tenkara flies, and a spool of tippet.We guarantee the delivery of all the perks, our reputation depends on it and we are an established company with great reputation we want to keep.Tenkara Addict Video Review of the Mutant Prototype How To Use a Multi-Length Zoom Tenkara Rod

story:
Hammocks are the best. We’ve never met one we didn’t enjoy relaxing in but they’re NOT perfect - here’s why:

  • Good spots are hard to find - Trees too far apart or too small
  • Antisocial - Fits two people at most 
  • Not Adaptable - Strung up or useless

So we set out to re-imagine the hammock. Six months later and we’re proud to introduce to you the M.C. Hammie. It's a hammock, shelter, blanket all-in-one.

 

It’s the solution to a problem we call “All The Things”. We grew tired of bringing a small mountain of stuff with us on daily adventures, so we decided to do something about it.

 

Unlike other hammocks, it's designed to be shared with friends. It'll keep all your besties off the dusty, wet ground one day...

 

then, out of the sun and drizzle the next...

 

and is always ready for hammock time...

 

perfect for just about anything...

 

 

The special sauce lies in the integrated straps and carabiners. With a shake it’s a blanket.... 

 

 with a pull it’s a hammock.... 

 

 and with a pop it’s a shelter....

Materials and Hardware:

  • The M.C. Hammie is made with the same high performance materials commonly found in premium tents and select hammocks. The primary material is a DWR Diamond Ripstop Nylon that is durable and water repellent. 

     

  • Diamond Patterned Ripstop Nylon is durable, super soft, and packs down small. Equally useful at the beach or your backyard.

     

  • We've used eight premium aluminum carabiners throughout the design for their light, durable, and smooth clipping.

     

  • Built to last, we've put triple and double stitching where it maters most.

     

  • Most hammocks overlook the versatility gained from simple nylon loops. They have a big impact on multi-use-ability so we designed them in.

     

  • The included Get Down aluminum ground stakes keep the M.C. Hammie in blanket mode, while the included cord can be used to fashion yourself a shade or rain shelter.

    M.C. Hammie Includes:

    1x Attached Ripstop Nylon Carry Pouch - aka: beer holder
    6x Get Down Aluminum Ground Stakes
    8x Aluminum Carabiners - aka: clip combos for daaaays
    12’ Paracord Line
    2x Freedom Tree Straps - aka: freebie ya'll! Only for backers ( $30 value)

     

     

      

     

     

    We met on the Eastern slopes of the Gnar'yall range. Rick worked as a pigmy goat merchant, while Adam worked on his tan... just playing. We met at a co-working space in Bend.

    We have started Wildish to mix things up a bit. Hopefully, alot. We are outdoorsy homies looking to make outdoorsy gear everyone can use. Not too extreme or spendy and definitely not under designed and boring. We think It’s time for more fun, smart stuff.


    Did you know Rick has a background in engineering and Adam is a design expert? We both have helped build and manage major consumer product companies as 9-to-5ers for over a decade. We tell you this to let you know we are professionals... but still goobers.

    We are motivated by family, friends, and nature, animals, coffee, and sweats. Our plan is to build an international community of Wildish outdoorsy folk who just get what we are doing and want to participate in the journey. Sounds simple enough, you in?

    Thanks for stopping by,
    Rick and Adam

 

 

 

Risks and challenges

We’ve been in business long enough to know there are always risks. We're committed to getting this right, that's a promise. Here are a few risks and challenges that we've thought of:

Product Manufacturing Delays

• We've already done production runs of our Mr. Big Stuff blanket so we're confident in our manufacturers; however, factories can have unforeseen setbacks.
• We stay in constant communication with our manufacturers from prototype to production to assure the highest quality end product.
• We always work on-site with our manufacturer for new products to resolve any challenges quickly and efficiently.

Shipping Delays

• We are choosey about who we ship with and will try to find the quickest and most reliable delivery service for our backers.
• We will do our best to ship to the earliest backers first and work our way back till y'all have one.

Lost Packages

• We’ve had some experience shipping products internationally, which means we know things can get lost.
• We're selecting our shipment partners to minimize issues but if problems do arise we're committed to make sure your reward gets into your hands.

Please email us at support@staywildish.com if you have any direct questions or concerns.

story:
I am a biologist and photographer, having lived these passions through the 1980s until today. I believe there is a power through photography to celebrate nature, awaken preservation consciousness, and to promote its stewardship.

Brazil has one of the largest bird species diversities in the world, yet its fauna has greatly suffered due to habitat destruction, rainforest deforestation, and illegal poaching. The aim of this campaign is to further publicize the beauty of Brazil’s remaining bird populations, their habitat, and to raise awareness of the importance of action for preservation.

Brazil has continental dimensions and avifauna specific to each region. The first phase of this campaign will explore the Southeast and Midwest, the regions where bird habitats have been most degraded by agribusiness and urbanization. We hope to promote awareness and ultimately action to maintain and restore the birds of Brazil.

The photography book will be avaliable on december/2017.

story:
About me

My name is Chris Scott I am a photographer and an artist. I enjoy traveling and taking my camera and exploring new places and connecting with new people whom I meet along the way.

I have had many experiences so far in life some joyous and some challenging. Through all that I have gained and lost I have learned a lot and that has brought me to where I am today and has greatly influenced my work. I began my journey after high school when I pursued a degree in graphic design and after completing my education, I was devastated to learn I had been diagnosed with Lymphoma. With my  future uncertain I decided to fight the disease and to reach my dream of having a career in photography.

After being completely in remission I chose to attend The School of the Art Institute of Chicago. I am now proud to say that after three wonderful years of meeting many new friends and inspirational instructors who helped me become the artist I am today,  I have graduated with a bachelors in fine arts with a focus in photography.


My work

 I enjoy using unusual techniques and old cameras to take photos. Each old camera I own has a unique lens and its own unique vision of the world which creates a photograph that is special and one of a kind. I have done many projects about the people of a community and the places and spaces that surround them. I have previously used my camera to explore urban sprawl and the communities in Detroit and small towns and forests of Michigan, I have also traveled many places throughout the United States and used my cameras to capture my experiences along the way.

Lake Michigan 2013 Diana Camera

Sculpture at Chicago Art Museum 2014 Foldex Camera

San Antonio Mission Holga Camera


The Project

I am proposing a project in which I would travel to Europe and eventually make my way to France and to Paris making stops along the way to capture the street scenes and people. I have always believed that the best way to connect to a place and meet new people is to take my camera with me wherever I go, taking photos of places and talking to those who live in those places. My project will consist of me traveling to several cities and villages, both large and small in France and taking unique photos with older cameras to capture modern Europe through older lenses. This project will not end here, this is only the beginning. My hope is that I will be able to continue to travel and document every new country I visit. Allowing me an opportunity to explore new cities and villages and meet new people,  creating a new series of photos and new photo books. With your help I will be able to reach these places and achieve my goal. 



How you Can Help

I am creating this page because this is a dream of mine to complete this journey. Unfortunately, due to numerous medical bills from my surgeries and doctor's visits and the large amount of student debt, without your gracious donations my dreams would have to be put on hold until much later.

All donations no matter how great or how small will help, from a simple $5 donation that will help buy me a roll of film to a larger donation that will help with airfare or other big expenses, all will be greatly appreciated!

story:
There is a lot of text coming up here - take a look at the Video and you'll get all the necessary info there. The text here are for those who loves details

We have received a donation outside Indiegogo, so we now have the finances for the required licenses!!! We are in fact up and running as a company now, taking in bookings.
And - We still appreciate any contributions you are willing to make :-)

 

“Make an impact - climb Kilimanjaro the fair trade way”

Richard Branson said, "Emplyees come first. If you take care of your employees, they will care for the clients."

Now, on a mountain side, going for the top, this is not just desirably, it is essential. 

So we just told you about the conditions, what we need and how we intend to ensure the payments of fair salaries.

Below you can chek all about how we intend to use the money we hope to get, find more info about working conditions about perks and a lot more. But first we would like to tell you about the kind of company we are creating

Introducing Stella Track

In order to make the climb as a team the climbers will be introduced to the crew at the starting gate. They will be presented with the name and responsibility of each crew member, so the climber knows who is carrying what, who is making the food and so on. This will eliminate any shadow workers – a shadow worker is someone who is not there. The climbers could be told there are fifteen workers when in reality there is only ten, it means there are five shadow workers. With fewer workers there are fewer to share the salary and the tip. A little more payment, a lot more work - and an appearance to be kept.

Stella Track will be an open and transparent company where the crew will not have to pretend. The climbers will be able to approach any of the team members and walk freely around the camp while all the crew will be completely at ease, because there will be no inaccuracies to hide.

This was agreed upon in a meeting we had with porters and guides who we are going to work with.

We also talked about the possibility of eating together. This could be fixed with tourists having pasta, the crew ugali and then they would all have the same sauce – the problem was the mess tent. If everyone should  eat together the mess tent would have to be huge – and more porters would be needed to carry it.

Instead they suggested people would eat separately like now, and then the climbers could come over and have their tea with the crew outdoor. They would also be welcome to visit the crew area and take pictures of the food being made, for instance.

Again, this was a suggestion from the crew. A proud way of showing there is nothing to hide in this company. Here we work together and we all freely enjoy each other’s company. We all agreed this would be the way to do it.

 

Meet the crew:

Here are a few of the people who are going to work with Stella Track. Not everyone are willing to put their picture up here as they at the moment are working with other companies. 

 

The wishes of the Crew

This is the wish list from the crew. Please bare in mind, since this is a wishlist from the crew it is also a list of things that would not necessarily be in place in other companies. Apart from decent salaries, this is what we aim for

  • If tip is included in the salary, then there is no need for taking unnecessary risks in order to secure a good tip.  The concern about getting a good tip or not, is eliminated and everyone can concentrate on the climb and the security of it.
  • We need to have a written company policy for everyone to read and agree to.
  • What if a climber is not feeling to good and has read a lot about things on the internet and insists on going down, even if it is not necessary? The opinion here was that the guide is educated and know the signs to be aware of. The tourists should listen to the guide. In case of a tourist scared beyond reasoning, the guides know how to deal with them, and help them. This is their responsibility. They are trained for this.
  • First aid training for all of the crew, not only the guides
  • Other cources too, like english or cultural understanding.
  • The climbers must fill in a health statement so the crew knows if anyone have special needs. Bad knees are not an issue if the crew knows about it – they can take special precautions for this. And if a climber lies, we have it on writing what they told us, and it is their responsibility if something goes wrong. No guide or porter should risk losing their job for something they had no clue about.
  • We need to carry oxygen and oximeter with us. If we should be in need of this, we should never be in a situation where we have to run to other groups or companies and borrow. Never!
  • When we have big groups – like in really big – we also need to have radios, so the guides can communicate in areas where there is no mobile cover.
  • As we grow as company we should also have all the kitchen gear, for a start the cook will bring his own, but eventually it would be great if we as a company have our own.
  • Some food can not be stored, like meat and fruit. One guide asks if we could skip one or two porters in the start of the climb and have them join later with fresh supplies. Another guide says we should go with the amount of crew required and if we need fruit or meat at the end of the climb, then this should be sent by the company as addition
  • One guide suggests we get ourselves a mini gas bottle with bulb. This can be used in the mess tent both as light and as heater, making it nice for the climbers while they wait for the food to be ready.
  • If it at one point will be possible it would be great if we could supply mountain gears, since this is very expensive. But if we can not, it is ok. (It was clear they did not want to ask for too much)

  • We should also state on the website that we will end the climb with the climbers and crew saying thank you and goodbye to each other. The crew will sing a song for the tourists as farewell – and this is just a song, not a plea for tip, as tips will be included in the salary.

 

Why is this important to the customer, the climber?

These are Helenas pictures from when she climbed Kilimanjaro in 2013. This is not 20-25 kg...

First of all not paying your crew a decent salary simply is not fair . Not to the Porters and not to the Adventurer who spent years saving for this trip. -  But furthermore it creates risks.

Climbing Kilimanjaro is an adventure of a lifetime, many people have been saving for years to do this. But what if the porters carrying all the luggage and equipment for the tourist adventurer, are not get anything from the company for it ? If they  depend solely on the tip you are able to pay them. If the tea the porters are enjoying as the tourists are having breakfast or lunch, is not after meal tea; it is the meal itself. Then what?

If the income is the tip, it becomes overly important to ensure the tip. Then the wishes of the customer becomes more important than company polices, or security gudielines. You might ignore important safety issues in order to keep your unaware customer happy enough to pay you a good tip. 

If porters have not eaten properly or does not have a proper sleeping bag, if they are tired from carrying 35 kg on the back - then the people supposed to ensure your climb, might become a security risk them self.

Is this the kind of climb you would like? 

How would I know?

Climbs up Kilimanjaro comes in most price levels. Low price companies, ie 1500 USD pr pax pr climb, or less, does not get enough revenue to pay the guide and porters a decent salary.

Porters are hired for each climb. Often the guides are the ones both hiring and handing out the wages to the porters, which is done in cash. The requirement is three porters per climber. With fewer porters there are fewer to share the portion of payment. It is possible to  get in with more weight than the official limit of 20 kg pr porter.

Now these conditions have been documented by others as well

Student documentary from 2011  
How Porters are treated, by African Zoom. 2015
A tourists experience from 2014
Porters of Kilimanjaro, 2012

The very people who ensures all the climbers achieving their goals should not be treated this way. The climbers finally having their goal of their dreams within reach should not have this experience stained by unknowingly being part of this oppressing system.

Gathering the team

Our story is simple: Scandinavian Helena and Tanzanian Jacob met when Jacob took Helena to the top of Kilimanjaro, where he, at the time,had been working for 13 years. (Long story very short: they fell in love and are now married.)

Helena saw people working their butts off on the trail up the mountain, some of them carrying way too much. Many of them without proper gear or even proper clothings. Jacob later explained that not all workers were treated fair on the mountain. Even though there are both guidelines and rules for this there was no consequence for not meeting the standards and many were the workers who worked far too much for far too little.

If only there was a Tanzanian company who would treat their workers fair, Jacob said.
Let’s create one! - Jacob and Helena said simultaneously laughing

Ramona from Romania and Monika from Bulgaria had been studying entrepreneurship in Scandinavia together with Helena, and they soon joined in. Together the four of them started Stella Track, a company who offers climbs up Kilimanjaro where the crew is treated fair, paid reasonable payments, and where climbers and crew work together as a full team.

Mobile payments

But choosing to pay a little more does not in itself, solve the problem of fair payment. In order to be sure the payments go straight to the correct porter, cook or guide Stella Track will use mobile payments for paying salary and tip. An idea Monika came up with.

You see, in East Africa everybody has a mobile phone and mobile payments, is a well established system. More well established than in most western countries, actually.  Using the mobile payment system will also mean that apart from Stella Track the payments will be registered by the phone companies. In other words, all payments will be registered by a third, completely independant, party.

Jacob and Helena had a meeting with some of the guides, porters, and cooks who work on Kilimanjaro. Together they drew the outlines for Stella Track and how the crew would like a company like this to work.

This business idea is for a large part formed by the crew. 

 

Finances

Now this is all well, but it does not pay itself. In order to be able to provide this for the very people who makes the adventures possible for the climbers, we need money. There are licenses to be paid and gear to be bought and this is where we need your help.

We need to raise at least $33000 to get our company started. We also need to pay 18% in tax in Tanzania, from our crowdfunding income. To end up with $33000 we actually need to get $40000. This capital will enable us to cover our initial start up costs, from getting the right gear to paying the licenses required. After this, climbs sold should pay for expenses and salaries for each climb.

If there is one climb with 5 people, we need 1 guide, 2 assistant guides, 1 cook and 15 porters and one extra porter if they want a portable camptoilet with them. 

Crew gear for 20 people

Then there are other equipments, like different tents. Then messtent for eating and relaxing. 3 larger tents for the crew to sleep in. They want to sleep many together as this keeps up the warmth in the tent. A kitchen tent for cooking, often the cook sleeps here too. With five people we might be able to carry out with 4, 2-pax tents, if there is one couple among them. 

Then there is safety equipment, cooking gear and so on.

Equipment for a group with 5 climbers and 20 crew members

Administration costs

We are pleased to let you know we have the capital necessary to get the licenses needed. The rest of the costs in this picture should be paid with the income from climbs..

What if we dont reach the amount we are aiming for?

Well, your money will not have been lost. We will start with whatever amount we reach. We will use the first sold trips to rent equipment until we have earned enough on sales, to buy our own.  We would definitely prefer to reach our goal here on Indiegogo - but if not, we will go ahead anyway with what we have.

 

Is 33000 $ enough to fund an entire tour company?

No. But it would get us started. After that the climbs should pay for running the company. It is our leap of faith assumption climbers will be willing to pay for decent working conditions for their mountain crew.

 And it all starts right here with you.

 

Here is how you can help:

1: Donate to our campaign

2: Share our campaign on social media

3: Follow and share us on Facebook: StellaTrack

4: Come climb with us, and rate us on Tripadviser

 

Are there any perks?

A perk is great but can be costly. We would really like to spend your donations on the crew, as you intended. We all know that the real reward is being a part of something that matters and we all enjoy being acknowledged. So here are the deals:

Everyone who donates get to be mentioned on our "wall of fame"

$5: Digital Photo of Kilimanjaro

$10: Kilimanjaro fun fact

$25: Fact sheet and Photo of Kili

$30: Badge with "Stella Track" logo

$40: Physical Postcard

$50: "Stella Track" T-Shirt

$75: Choose perk (1 item)

$90: Choose perk (2 items)

$100: Choose perk (3 items)

$500: Free private tour to Materuni (for 1 person)

$1,000: Free safari in Tanzania (for 1 person)

$10,000: Free climb on Kilimanjaro (for 2 persons)

 

Are there any risks?

We would be lying if we said "There are not any risks". There is the potential that tourists will not care if their guides and porters are being paid or not, and just go for cheaper climbs. Building a start up is full of challenges and it might fail, and the world will spin on with or without us.  

But if we succeed then we can do our part to improve a tiny part of the world for years to come - and you  helped make it possible.

If you choose to come on one of our tours, here is what we offer:

In a 7 day climb the following is included:

• A general feel-good, knowing your guide and porters receive proper payment: 30 USD pr day to the guides and 18 USD a day to the porters. The assistant guide gets 27 and the chef receives 23 USD a day
• Climb Kilimanjaro via Machame route (Whiskey route)
• Transfers between the airport and your hostel
• 2 nights at a hotel in Moshi, an overnight stay before and after the climb
• Breakfast at the hostel
• Transfers between your hotel and the gate on Kilimanjaro
• Entry fee for Kilimanjaro
• Camp fee for 6 nights on Kilimanjaro using a purpose built tent
• Full board on the climb
• All food during the climb is prepared on location by a local chef
• Professional guides
• 3 porters pr person
• Tip, is included in the above mensioned salary. Meaning you do not tip after the climb, as this is already done.
• Back up program, should you have to have to go down prior to your group.
• An adventure of a lifetime

This package does not include:

• Flights – we recommend you book these well ahead to get a good price. Try momondo.com or skyrunner.com to find the best prices for your flights.
• Visa to Tanzania. Can be obtained on arrival at the Tanzanian airport and costs 50 USD
• Vaccines – talk to your doctor (as non medics we are not allowed to advice in medical matters, including what vaccines to take)
• Travel insurance - Get one! You will so regret not having one, if you need it.
story_txt:
There is a lot of text coming up here - take a look at the Video and you'll get all the necessary info there. The text here are for those who loves detailsWe have received a donation outside Indiegogo, so we now have the finances for the required licenses!!! We are in fact up and running as a company now, taking in bookings.And - We still appreciate any contributions you are willing to make :-) “Make an impact - climb Kilimanjaro the fair trade way”Richard Branson said, "Emplyees come first. If you take care of your employees, they will care for the clients."Now, on a mountain side, going for the top, this is not just desirably, it is essential. So we just told you about the conditions, what we need and how we intend to ensure the payments of fair salaries.Below you can chek all about how we intend to use the money we hope to get, find more info about working conditions about perks and a lot more. But first we would like to tell you about the kind of company we are creatingIntroducing Stella TrackIn order to make the climb as a team the climbers will be introduced to the crew at the starting gate. They will be presented with the name and responsibility of each crew member, so the climber knows who is carrying what, who is making the food and so on. This will eliminate any shadow workers – a shadow worker is someone who is not there. The climbers could be told there are fifteen workers when in reality there is only ten, it means there are five shadow workers. With fewer workers there are fewer to share the salary and the tip. A little more payment, a lot more work - and an appearance to be kept.Stella Track will be an open and transparent company where the crew will not have to pretend. The climbers will be able to approach any of the team members and walk freely around the camp while all the crew will be completely at ease, because there will be no inaccuracies to hide.This was agreed upon in a meeting we had with porters and guides who we are going to work with.We also talked about the possibility of eating together. This could be fixed with tourists having pasta, the crew ugali and then they would all have the same sauce – the problem was the mess tent. If everyone should  eat together the mess tent would have to be huge – and more porters would be needed to carry it.Instead they suggested people would eat separately like now, and then the climbers could come over and have their tea with the crew outdoor. They would also be welcome to visit the crew area and take pictures of the food being made, for instance.Again, this was a suggestion from the crew. A proud way of showing there is nothing to hide in this company. Here we work together and we all freely enjoy each other’s company. We all agreed this would be the way to do it. Meet the crew:Here are a few of the people who are going to work with Stella Track. Not everyone are willing to put their picture up here as they at the moment are working with other companies.  The wishes of the CrewThis is the wish list from the crew. Please bare in mind, since this is a wishlist from the crew it is also a list of things that would not necessarily be in place in other companies. Apart from decent salaries, this is what we aim for
If tip is included in the salary, then there is no need for taking unnecessary risks in order to secure a good tip.  The concern about getting a good tip or not, is eliminated and everyone can concentrate on the climb and the security of it.
We need to have a written company policy for everyone to read and agree to.
What if a climber is not feeling to good and has read a lot about things on the internet and insists on going down, even if it is not necessary? The opinion here was that the guide is educated and know the signs to be aware of. The tourists should listen to the guide. In case of a tourist scared beyond reasoning, the guides know how to deal with them, and help them. This is their responsibility. They are trained for this.
First aid training for all of the crew, not only the guides
Other cources too, like english or cultural understanding.
The climbers must fill in a health statement so the crew knows if anyone have special needs. Bad knees are not an issue if the crew knows about it – they can take special precautions for this. And if a climber lies, we have it on writing what they told us, and it is their responsibility if something goes wrong. No guide or porter should risk losing their job for something they had no clue about.
We need to carry oxygen and oximeter with us. If we should be in need of this, we should never be in a situation where we have to run to other groups or companies and borrow. Never!
When we have big groups – like in really big – we also need to have radios, so the guides can communicate in areas where there is no mobile cover.
As we grow as company we should also have all the kitchen gear, for a start the cook will bring his own, but eventually it would be great if we as a company have our own.
Some food can not be stored, like meat and fruit. One guide asks if we could skip one or two porters in the start of the climb and have them join later with fresh supplies. Another guide says we should go with the amount of crew required and if we need fruit or meat at the end of the climb, then this should be sent by the company as addition
One guide suggests we get ourselves a mini gas bottle with bulb. This can be used in the mess tent both as light and as heater, making it nice for the climbers while they wait for the food to be ready.
If it at one point will be possible it would be great if we could supply mountain gears, since this is very expensive. But if we can not, it is ok. (It was clear they did not want to ask for too much)
We should also state on the website that we will end the climb with the climbers and crew saying thank you and goodbye to each other. The crew will sing a song for the tourists as farewell – and this is just a song, not a plea for tip, as tips will be included in the salary.

story:
Our Story

We are a Christian couple looking to go on our first mission trip! We attend Word of Life Christian Center in Lonetree CO www.wolcc.net, and are hoping to be a part of the 2012 Miracle Crusade in Guapiles, Costa Rica with Aaron Bagwell Ministries. Our passion is seeing Godâ€™s healing power, the sick healed and lives saved! The trip is the last week in March and will last for 7 days.  To see video for this mission trip and more information on Aaron Bagwell Ministries go to www.aaronbagwell.org. If you donate directly on this website please inform them it is for Alicia Roberts or Paul Boykin. Thank you.


The Impact

For 7 days we will hit the streets, schools, orphanages, and homes to touch peoples lives with the Gospel. We will be doing the work of the Kingdom of God- laying our hands on the sick, declaring blessings and overflow for each family and bringing lives back to Christ. Tuesday-Saturday are Crusade nights where a large soccer stadium will be filled with thousands of people who need a word from Heaven and a healing, powerful touch of God. We anticipate reaching tens of thousands of people; men, women, children. "Go therefore and make disciples of all the nations..." Matt 28:19


What We Need & What You Get

The entire trip costs $1500 each person. The money will cover all costs including lodging, food, and transportation. Every dollar donation is a tax write off. If we go over our $3000.00 mark the rest of the money will go towards the mission trip and specifically to touch the lives of the people in Costa Rica. If we do not meet our $3000 goal all monies will still go to help this ministry for the mission trip. Any donation is appreciated and will not return to you void! Your donation will not only bless the people of Costa Rica, but it will bless YOU!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out about this mission trip! In 2002 I studied Spanish at Universidad de Veritas in Costa Rica and was greatly affected by the people there. Ten years later I get to return to touch the lives of the people I grew to love!

story:
House fire relief for a deserving veteran

Mr. Jeff Dempsey is a Marine and close friend to us, the family and friends of Corporal John Stalvey. In fact we first met him when he was tasked to deliver the news that we had lost John and to help coordinate the funeral. He was there for us to lean on when we needed it most. I mean that more sincerely than I can express.

Unfortunately, Mr. Dempsey has recently lost his home to fire.

For the past year we have been operating the Cpl John Stalvey Foundation specifically to help veterans in honor of their service and in honor of John's memory and legacy. Perhaps you have participated as a sponsor, event participant or just as a friend of our fan page. Whatever the case may be we want you to know that your involvement has directly led us to this day, when we have the honor to help this fine Marine. If you are hearing of our foundation or this situation for the first time, you're not too late. The Board of the Cpl John Stalvey Foundation has met and decided that we will do what we can to help and we are more than happy to do so. We will be donating the funds we have received to date along with what is donated over the next 2 weeks via this online fundraiser. So please consider what you may do to help and thank you for joining with us in this cause. No amount is too small.

And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity.
